G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������ which allows the Probate and Family Court to modify child custody and visitation orders upon a material change in circumstances that affects the welfare of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The requested modifications are necessary to serve the childs best interests, which are paramount under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that under G.L. c. 208, §30, removal decisions turn on whether the move is in the child’s best interests, and repeatedly characterizes the child’s best interests as the paramount concern in the analysis. The court explains that all factors, including the custodial parent’s and noncustodial parent’s interests, are evaluated through the lens of what serves the child’s best interests, confirming that this standard is controlling under Massachusetts law.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000).
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody or visitation order may be modified upon a showing that (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) the modification is necessary to serve the best interests of the child.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Zia deals with an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and the general best-interests standard. It does not address the standard for *modification* of an existing custody or visitation order, nor does it discuss any requirement of a prior ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ as a predicate to modification. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the two-prong modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .” R. H. v. B. F., 39 Mass. App. Ct. at 39. See Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987); Carr v. Carr, 44 Mass. App. Ct. at 925; Freedman v. Freedman, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 519, 522 (2000), and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute.”}

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003);.proposition: Courts have long held that the childs best interests are the touchstone of any custody or visitation determination, and the childs welfare must predominate over parental convenience.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003);.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and reaffirms the longstanding rule that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the touchstone in custody and visitation matters and that the child’s welfare is paramount. The court traces this standard historically, cites prior Massachusetts precedents using language such as ‘paramount concern’ and ‘welfare of the child,’ and applies it as the governing test in resolving the custody dispute, as opposed to parental claims or convenience.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003);.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009)..proposition: Courts have long held that the childs best interests are the touchstone of any custody or visitation determination, and the childs welfare must predominate over parental convenience.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009)..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of alimony obligations upon a supporting spouse’s retirement, not custody or visitation. It does not articulate or apply a ‘best interests of the child’ standard, nor discuss weighing child welfare against parental convenience. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about children’s best interests in custody or visitation determinations.

D.C. v. J.S., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (20.raw_text: D.C. v. J.S., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (2003) (rescript);
D.C. v. J.S., 58 Mass. App. Ct. 1111 (20.proposition: A parents relocation can constitute a material change in circumstances if it disrupts an existing custody plan or poses challenges to the childs well-being.

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: A parents relocation can constitute a material change in circumstances if it disrupts an existing custody plan or poses challenges to the childs well-being.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a custodial parent’s request to relocate out of state and the proper application of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best-interests framework under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not analyze or hold that relocation, as such, constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances” because it disrupts an existing custody plan or affects the child’s well-being. The only discussion of material change is to correct the trial judge’s error and state that the mother’s remarriage itself is a material and substantial change under § 28; the court does not frame the relocation as the material change described in the proposition.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28… Changed circumstances are those that occur subsequent to the judgment of divorce or subsequent to a prior modification… In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001);
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: It is well-established that courts must consider the impact of travel on the minor child, particularly when it interferes with the childs rest, education, or physical and emotional health.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses relocation standards and the need to consider the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, and the effect of curtailed association with a parent, but it does not focus on or articulate any principle about the burden of travel itself on the child (rest, education, or health). The only travel-related discussion concerns the logistical burden on the mother and the reasonableness of visitation arrangements, not impacts like fatigue or interference with schooling or health. Thus it does not establish the specific proposition that courts must consider the impact of travel on the minor child in the manner claimed.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “No findings were made that specifically address the effect on Caleb of a possible ‘curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent,’ in the event of relocation. Id. at 711. In light of the fact that the distance between Northborough and Providence is but fifty-five miles and has not precluded significant access to both parents, it is likely that by living in Providence the effect on Caleb’s association with the father would be no greater than the effect on the child’s association with the mother if he were to remain in Northborough.”

Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (2002) (rescript).
Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: It is well-established that courts must consider the impact of travel on the minor child, particularly when it interferes with the childs rest, education, or physical and emotional health.
Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 90.case_name: Tilton v. Union Oil Co. of California
Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns products liability, the bulk supplier doctrine, and evidentiary issues in a workplace injury case. It does not involve custody, visitation, or any issue related to the impact of travel on a minor child’s rest, education, or health. Therefore, it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about considering travel’s impact on a minor child.
Connor v. Benedict, 56 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: In Massachusetts, a manufacturer who knows or should know that its product is inherently dangerous or in a dangerous condition is “under a duty to give warning of those dangers to ‘persons who it is foreseeable will come in contact with, and consequently be endangered by, that product.’ ” MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131, 135, cert. denied, 474 U.S. 920 (1985), quoting from H.P. Hood & Sons v. Ford Motor Co., 370 Mass. 69, 75 (1976). However, a manufacturer is deemed to have discharged its duty if it could justifiably rely on the intermediary purchaser to warn such foreseeable users of the product’s dangers...

Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 81 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 81 Mass. App. Ct. 479 (2012).
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 81 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: In light of the evidence that Emilys well-being is detrimentally impacted by the current midweek overnight arrangement due to exhaustion and disrupted school performance, the requested modification is in her best interests.
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 81 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modifying a midweek overnight schedule based on evidence of a child’s exhaustion and impaired school performance. Prenaveau deals with interstate relocation, broader custody allocation, and general best‑interest factors such as stability, continuity, shuttling, and parental cooperation. The opinion does not discuss midweek overnights, school fatigue, or academic disruption as a basis for modification, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Prenaveau v. Prenaveau, 81 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Several criteria of the child’s best interests have emerged from the major precedents on removal and custody. A long-established guideline is the objective of stability and continuity in the life of the child… A second criterion is the maximum involvement and participation of both parents… A third objective… is the reduction of disruptive shuttle transport of children between custodial parents.”
